options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: NA
This was a live virtual lecture of seminar size.
The primary mode of learning was live, virtual lectures.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course provides an introduction to environmental transport phenomena and discusses the implications for environmental contamination.
I learned about the mechanisms and mathematical derivations behind mass transfer and transport processes, as well as groundwater contamination.
Transport processes in relation to environmental engineering, fluid mechanics, groundwater flow, transport of chemicals in environmental systems

This course gives great technical background into environmental transport phenomena, especially as it relates to the movement of pollutants in and around water and groundwater. We thought creatively about intricate problems using advanced calculus to solve. We also learned about modern advances in the field of water quality and filtration, especially as it relates to Professor Elimelech's fascinating research.
I gained a thorough understanding of transport phenomena and the interfaces between physical states.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Prof. Elimelech is an awesome professor! He presented the material at a good pace and had really neatly written out notes. It was always easy to follow the flow of the material. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes the homework assignments were confusing and didn't connect well with what we had learned in class.

The professor was clear in his lectures, and always reviewed material from the previous class, which was very helpful. The pace of the lectures was good and I was able to follow along. The homework problems were challenging but interesting. I do wish that there were more review problems in preparation for the exams.
This was a great class and Meny is a wonderful professor! The only way that the course could be improved would be by being in person, but obviously, that was not a possibility this semester.

This is a very rigorous and fun course. It taught us how to break down environmental problems with a rigorous approach, stating our assumptions, coordinate systems, and governing equations to solve. The class is very organized and thorough, and could perhaps use some more breakout rooms to try to solve some of the problems in class on our own.

The strengths of the course were in the homework and the instruction. Meny did an excellent job teaching and the homework led to an increased understanding of the topics. The aspect that could have been improved is a more clear distinction between the types of diffusion to help students identify the system correctly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The format was powerpoint slides with images of handwritten notes. This format worked ok, but at some times, it was hard to take notes at the same pace as the material was being presented.
The online lectures and online office hours with the TF worked fine. The comfortable pace of the lectures allowed me to stay engaged.
I was really pleased with the way Meny organized the virtual course, especially by making the lectures shorter. Great class!

Professor Elimelech's energy during Zoom lectures was essential in keeping us excited and engaged, and I am very happy I got to take his class. I think some more breakout rooms would have been helpful to engage more with other students in the class and the material.
The course translated very well virtually. The professor learned the mode of instruction thoroughly and was able to very clearly explain the topics with helpful slides to demonstrate the derivations.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Prof Elimelech is an awesome professor and you learn about important environmental processes
Yes, I think the concepts would be useful for any engineering student (especially chemical and environmental), and Meny is a great professor.
Yes if you are an environmental engineering major you definitely need to take a course with Meny!
Highly recommend this class to other engineers and scientists who appreciate mathematical rigor, with interest in environmental problems. Also, for those who want to learn from Professor Elimelech!
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. While the content could be difficult at times, the instruction was excellent and there were plenty of opportunities to ask questions.
